'Meteor Lake' First Tests: Intel Core Ultra 7 Benched for CPU, Graphics, and AI Performance

We got a fresh-updated Acer Swift Go 14 laptop into PC Labs for our first independent benchmarking of Intel's AI-ready Core Ultra processors. Let's run the numbers!
By Charles Jefferies
Charles Jefferies
My Experience

Computers are my lifelong obsession. I wrote my first laptop review in 2005 for NotebookReview.com, continued with a consistent PC-reviewing gig at Computer Shopper in 2014, and moved to PCMag in 2018. Here, I test and review the latest high-performance laptops and desktops, and sometimes a key core PC component or two. I also review enterprise computing solutions for StorageReview.

Read Full Bio
December 14, 2023
Facebook
Twitter
Reddit
Social Share
Reddit Pinterest Flipboard LinkedIn Email
Copied
Error!
Copy Link
https://www.pcmag.com/news/meteor-lake-first-tests-intel-core-ultra-7-benched-for-cpu-graphics-and
Comments
(Credit: Joseph Maldonado)

Intel’s next-generation “Meteor Lake” processors have arrived in laptops, bringing local artificial intelligence (AI) crunching silicon to mainstream mobile Windows 11 PCs through the chip giant's new neural processing unit (NPU). Thanks to a brand-new Swift Go 14 laptop provided to us by Acer, we've conducted a host of benchmarks on one of the first production models featuring an Intel Core Ultra 7 chip.

The new Intel Core Ultra line is much more than a major rebrand, introducing Intel’s new microarchitecture, hugely improved integrated graphics, and the firm's new 7-nanometer (7nm) manufacturing process, in addition to its first generation of AI processing hardware. Here's what we found to shout about in the first set of Intel Core Ultra 7 numbers. (We also have speeds and feeds on all the new chips announced today.)

What’s New With Meteor Lake?

We already have a Meteor Lake deep-dive linked above that covers the ins and outs of this new microarchitecture, but let’s do a quick recap.

Meteor Lake is Intel’s biggest architectural shift in more than 40 years. The chip maker had produced "monolithic" silicon chips (where all parts of the CPU exist on the same chip) up to this point, with all components manufactured at the same time. Meteor Lake upends that with Intel’s Foveros packing technology that uses 3D “stacking” to combine separate components into the same chip. This is such a fundamental change because the pieces, called "chiplets" or "tiles," can be manufactured and designed separately. The advantages from this are profound and many: For instance, newer CPU cores could be dropped into an existing chip while keeping the rest of it the same, minimizing time to market.

(Credit: René Ramos; Intel)

Foveros also improves the “binning” process. With monolithic design, even one key defective part of a CPU could render the entire chip defective and therefore useless. With Foveros, however, the defective components can be QA'd separately and, as a result, keep the rest of the chip from the reject pile. Think of Foveros as interchangeable parts on the smallest and most complicated scale imaginable.

Meteor Lake is also the first time we’re seeing the Intel 4 process node, which uses 7nm parts, a significant advancement from Intel 7, which is 10nm at the smallest. It also introduces special high-speed interconnects that allow all parts of the CPU to talk to each other.

You'll find four tiles that make up a Meteor Lake CPU:

  • Compute: The most advanced tile; featuring the Performance and Efficient cores

  • Graphics: Contains the Intel Arc or Intel Graphics integrated graphics processor

  • SoC: Contains the new Low Power Island E-cores, the NPU AI engine, wireless and display technologies (including Wi-Fi 6E and Wi-Fi 7), and the integrated memory controller

  • I/O: Handles external connections from technologies such as PCI Express Gen 5 and Thunderbolt 4

That’s just a quick recap—remember to hit our Meteor Lake deep-dive for more.

Intel Core Ultra 7: Detailing Intel's Latest H-Class Processor

We’ve performed our first Meteor Lake tests on an Acer Swift Go 14 ultraportable laptop with an Intel Core Ultra 7 155H processor with a 28-watt (28W) processor base power (PBP) rating. That last bit about the wattage seems odd: H-class chips have traditionally been rated for 45W, so why is this chip running at just 28W? In short, Intel has replaced its P-class processors (which existed in the 12th and 13th Gen Core chips) with a power-consumption-adjustable H-class. In essence, the 28W H-class is the new P-class.

That could be confusing for consumers, though. Unless you know the wattage of the H-class chip, you might not get all the performance you think you’re getting, as a 28W chip will have much less performance than a 45W chip, all else being equal. (Regardless, Meteor Lake will continue to provide a 15W U-class.)

As for the Core Ultra 7 155H, this chip has six Performance cores and 10 Efficient cores, giving it the ability to process 22 threads at once. (The P-cores support simultaneous multithreading.) The P-cores have a 3.8GHz base clock and a maximum turbo clock of 4.8GHz. The Swift Go 14 laptop pairs this CPU with 16GB of LPDDR5 memory running at 6,400MHz and Intel's own new-and-improved Arc integrated graphics.

Acer Swift Go 14: The Dime Tour

Our full review of this Swift Go 14 is forthcoming—it’s been redesigned since we last reviewed it—but here’s a quick tour. This laptop starts with a 14-inch, 1,920-by-1,200-pixel touch screen and an all-metal case design that measures 0.55 by 12.3 by 8.6 inches (HWD). It weighs about 3 pounds.

(Credit: Joseph Maldonado)

Opening the lid raises the chassis, allowing better airflow to the fans and creating a slight angle for typing. The large fan exhaust aims at the display hinge. I noticed the fans were on more often than not.

(Credit: Joseph Maldonado)

Connectivity includes two Thunderbolt 4 ports, an HDMI 2.1 video output, two USB 3.2 Type-A ports, and a MicroSD slot. The Swift has a fingerprint reader built into its power button and a high-resolution 1440p camera over the screen. The AI features in the Core Ultra 7 CPU allow the webcam to support Windows Studio Effects, such as automated background blur.

Testing the Intel Core Ultra 7 155H: CPU Performance

We've compared the new Intel chip within the Swift Go 14 with a cornucopia of laptops featuring different processors, including two differently configured Qualcomm Snapdragon Elite X "Oryon" reference laptops that show the potential of Qualcomm Oryon-based systems slated to debut in mid-2024. (Qualcomm's "Configuration A" below was set up in a much higher total device power-consumption regimen than "Configuration B"; hit the link for much more detail on that.)

We also included the Framework Laptop 13 and the Lenovo Yoga 9i Gen 8 with the Intel Core i7-1360P (the closest 13th Gen analogue to the Core Ultra 7 as configured here), the Intel Core i7-1255U-equipped Microsoft Surface Laptop 5 15-inch, the AMD Ryzen 7 7736U-equipped HP Dragonfly Pro, and the Apple M2 MacBook Air 15-inch.

This isn’t a perfect comparison by any means, especially since some of these machines use ARM-based processors (and the Qualcomm Oryon PCs were bulked out with 64GB of RAM), but we also want to see exactly how the latest available chips from all three providers perform. This array of machines should give you a ballpark idea of what to expect in 2024 (save for AMD's just-announced Ryzen 8000 series, which we haven't had the opportunity to test yet).

Our CPU tests include Cinebench 2024, which uses all cores and threads to render a complex image, and the cross-platform Geekbench 6.2, which has single- and- multi-threaded CPU stress tests.

Acer's Cinebench 2024 multi-threaded test doesn’t appear in these results because it either reported strange scores (see the screen below, 1.29 million Cinebench units is highly unlikely!) or crashed on our sample, something that’s likely software-related, tied to the very early nature of the platform. We were unable to get to the bottom of this at launch time, but will update this piece if and when we do. The single-core test appeared to run fine, though the Acer stood near the rear of the pack.

Meanwhile, the Acer showed its teeth in Cinebench 23 and Geekbench 6: It dominated the last-generation Cinebench test and posted hefty single-core and especially substantial multi-core Geekbench scores. Only the Snapdragon Elite X Oryon laptops outdid the Acer in the latter test.

Testing the Intel Core Ultra 7 155H: AI Performance

Now, we move on to UL’s Procyon AI inferencing test, a trial that illustrates relative AI operations on several local AI engines. On Windows PCs, UL's Procyon AI Inference benchmark meausures the performance of dedicated AI processing hardware using common machine-vision tasks across several different neural networks.

Subtests within the benchmark include a mobile-based image recognition test (MobileNet V3), comprehensive image classification (Inception V4), object detection in images (YOLO V3), image segmentation (DeepLab V3), AI image upscaling (Real-ESRGAN), and image subject recognition (ResNet 50). Lower times are better in all tests.

Recommended by Our Editors
'Meteor Lake' Architecture Detailed: What to Know About Intel's Next-Gen CPUs
Chiplet Chat: Q&A With Intel's Tim Wilson, SoC Design Head for 'Meteor Lake' CPUs
The 'Meteor Lake' NPU: Meet Intel's Dedicated Silicon for Local AI Processing

We used the Qualcomm SNPE engine for the ARM-based systems, while the Intel chips used Intel OpenVINO’s back end with integer calculations.

We have numbers for only a few of these units. The real comparison is between the Acer and the Framework 13, the only other Intel-powered laptop in this group that we had on hand to generate test results for, and lacking an NPU. The Acer dominated, with 215 points to 75, suggesting its built-in AI processing potential is much better than in previous-generation Intel chips relying on CPU and GPU alone. While it may seem that the Qualcomm reference designs blew the Intel Core Ultra away, they're working on a different test engine and therefore aren't necessarily all that comparable. More AI-focused tests will be necessary down the road to see how to weigh the different models at play.

Testing the Intel Core Ultra 7 155H: Graphics Performance

Our graphics performance tests include UL’s 3DMark Wild Life Extreme and the 1080p Aztec Ruins subtest from GFXBench for cross-platform comparisons and relative ease to run.

The Acer’s Intel Arc graphics proved faster than the previous-generation Intel Iris Xe graphics in the Framework, Lenovo, and Microsoft Surface laptops, with clear generational gains. However, it was still behind the Apple’s M2 chip and (in a surprise showing) couldn’t catch the Qualcomm laptops. Still, these numbers suggest that laptops using Intel Arc integrated graphics may be able to power some light, low-res 3D gaming without a dedicated graphics processor. We'll investigate integrated Arc's graphics potential more in coming reviews.

Testing the Intel Core Ultra 7 155H: Applications Performance

Our last test is the everyday-productivity benchmark PCMark 10, specifically the PCMark 10 Applications subtest that measures performance in an installed and licensed Microsoft Office suite, including Word, Excel, PowerPoint, and the like.

We have results for just the Acer and the two Qualcomm units here. The Acer didn’t beat them, but it came close, which is impressive since those Qualcomm units have demonstrated exceptionally speedy performance so far. It should suffice to say that the Intel Core Ultra 7 will be more than ready for the productivity apps you use the most.

Intel Core Ultra Teases Meteoric Gains in AI and Graphics

Our very first Intel Meteor Lake test results are promising, though plenty remains unanswered. The Core Ultra 7 in Acer’s Swift Go 14 demonstrated notable generational performance gains versus laptops featuring 12th and 13th Gen Intel Core chips, as well as an AMD Ryzen 7 7000 U-series laptop. It wasn’t quite a match for Qualcomm’s Snapdragon X Elite, but those were reference designs and not final products. The Snapdragon systems aren't expected until midyear 2024. Core Ultra systems, on the other hand, are here today. (See our hands-ons with Meteor Lake-based Lenovo ThinkPad X1 and MSI Prestige machines that are hitting the streets now.)

The biggest performance gains we saw from Meteor Lake were in AI performance, shocking no one, thanks to its onboard NPU. AI benchmarking needs to mature, though, to be able to make meaningful comparisons between platforms. We also noted significant bumps in integrated graphics performance from its onboard Intel Arc graphics, enough to suggest that light gaming might be possible without a dedicated GPU. We'll have to dig in with some games and the integrated Arc GPU after the launch and the initial driver updates.

Also: Overall, we feel like we just scratched the surface of what this platform is capable of, since the Core Ultra 7 155H we tested was limited to 28W of power. We can’t wait to see how it performs with the full 45W and in other variants. (Intel has unveiled eight Core Ultra chip SKUs so far, detailed in this article.) Stay tuned: More Meteor Lake laptops are streaking into PC Labs as you read this.

[Editor's Note, Dec. 21, 2023: Due to a data input error, in one of our performance charts we cited a Procyon AI score for the Apple MacBook Air 15-Inch. UL's Procyon AI test does not currently have a native macOS version; we have withdrawn those results from the relevant performance chart.]
